title: Chvrches' 'Love Is Dead' is a Pop Gem
summary: The first track is a fun summer vibe with acoustic guitar and a bass line that will make you want to dance. The lyrics are about being happy in the moment and not worrying about tomorrow because you donâ€™t know what it will bring. This song is a little darker than the first with lyrics about trying to forget a bad situation, but being unable to escape it. It features a heavy drum beat and a haunting synth melody. It's about needing a body guard because the world is a scary place.

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`In today\u2019s musical landscape, popular electronic music has taken over the pop world. But there are still some great pop albums that aren\u2019t filled with auto-tune and EDM drops.On May 25th, the Scottish band Chvrches released their third album called \u201C Love is Dead.\u201D The synth-pop band has lots of happy vibes and catchy hooks on their new album. It\u2019s a pleasant listen but might not be what you expect if you only know them from their first two albums. The band took a left turn creatively, covering topics like technology, isolation and death rather than dancing around in your bedroom to this record.
Chvrses has gained more popularity among a different group of fans by releasing this album than they ever did with their first two releases combined. This is partially because they have expanded their audience by collaborating on songs with Haim and Bleachers recently as well as making this change in sound so now they have crossover appeal to radio listeners too!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

content.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:t,...a}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...a,components:t,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("h2",null,"Track-by-track Review of \u201CLove Is Dead\u201D"),mdx("p",null,"Forever"),mdx("p",null,"This song is the first track on the album and is a fun summer vibe with acoustic guitar and a bass line that will make you want to dance. It\u2019s a catchy tune that sets the tone for the rest of the album, which is upbeat and optimistic. The lyrics are about being happy in the moment and not worrying about tomorrow because you don\u2019t know what it will bring. It\u2019s a great song to get you out of a funk."),mdx("p",null,"Never Hear Again"),mdx("p",null,"This song is a little darker than the first with lyrics about trying to forget a bad situation, but being unable to escape it. It features a heavy drum beat and a haunting synth melody. The chorus and vocals are catchy, with Lauren Mayberry singing about the fact that \u201Cthe world will never hear again,\u201D which is about how she doesn\u2019t want to hear about the old situation that upset her anymore."),mdx("p",null,"Deliverance"),mdx("p",null,"This song has a strong beat that makes you want to move. It has a strong bass line and a catchy synth melody. The lyrics are about rising above a bad situation and overcoming it to be stronger and more confident. The song talks about rising above the situation and turning it into something good."),mdx("p",null,"Graffiti On The Train Window"),mdx("p",null,"This tunes is slower than the others, but it has a catchy melody and has a really great message. The lyrics are about seeing something sad and wanting to do something about it but being too afraid so you \u201Cwrite it on the train window.\u201D It\u2019s about being an armchair activist and not actually making the change. The song is about realizing that you can actually make a difference if you don\u2019t stand idly by and do nothing."),mdx("p",null,"Body Guard"),mdx("p",null,"This song is a little different than the rest of the album because it\u2019s a little more aggressive and a little less upbeat. It\u2019s a little slower and doesn\u2019t have as many synths. It\u2019s about needing a body guard because the world is a scary place. It\u2019s a nice change of pace and brings a little variety to the album."),mdx("p",null,"Bottom Of The Ocean"),mdx("p",null,"This is another slower song on the album and sounds like it could be about a bad breakup. It\u2019s a little less upbeat and more somber than the rest of the record. It\u2019s about wanting to go back to a relationship that\u2019s over and wanting to \u201Cgo back to the bottom of the ocean where we started.\u201D It\u2019s about wanting to go back to a place where nothing bad has happened yet. It\u2019s a nice way to end the album with a somber tone."),mdx("p",null,"Thank you for reading."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: "The Imitation Game" Is a Fascinating Look at the Life of Alan Turing

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`In 1937, Alan Turing was born in Northern England. He would go on to become a war hero, pioneer of computer science, and one of the greatest minds of the 20th century. In 1951, he was convicted of \u201Cgross indecency\u201D and chemically castrated as punishment. Two years later, he killed himself with cyanide. This is his story.
Turing was a brilliant man with many interests that went beyond mathematics and computer science: chess, cryptography, music theory and programming computers to sing are just some examples. This diverse background helped him crack the Nazi Enigma code during World War II at Bletchley Park (which has been nicknamed "Codebreaking Castle"). This saved countless lives and accelerated the end of the war by two years. After the war ended in 1945, Turing continued working as an cryptanalyst for a few more years before turning his attention to other interests \u2013- and it is these interests that led to his arrest and untimely death at age 41.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: Beach House's '7' Is a Dreamy Masterpiece
"The Babadook" Is a Haunting and Original Horror Film
"Birdman" Is a Darkly Comic Meditation on Fame and Ego
"The Martian" Is a Triumph of Science Fiction

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Ridley Scott\u2019s new movie, The Martian, is based on a novel of the same name by Andy Weir. It\u2019s about an astronaut called Mark Watney who gets stranded on Mars after his crewmates think he\u2019s dead and leave without him. This might seem as just another case of annoying Hollywood over-simplification: after all, we get so many bioengineered super-geniuses with computer uplink implants that they can become trapped in remote locations via their own stupidity. But there\u2019s more to it than that.
In both book and film, the humanity of Watney comes out in everything he does to survive: logical thinking (how can I eat this potato again?), ingenuity (I need water; how do I distill it from our CO2 filters), courage (explore the abandoned outpost), and compassion (contact my family). He also has a lot of fun with his predicament, cracking jokes through his video log and even going disco.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: Charlie Puth's 'Voicenotes' Is a Solid Effort

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:t,...e}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...e,components:t,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Charlie Puth has been on a roll lately, with three top 40 hits in the last two years. He\u2019s also worked with some pretty big names (including one we\u2019ll get to shortly). Now, he\u2019s back with another new album, titled \u201CVoicenotes.\u201D It\u2019s a solid effort that shows growth and maturity, as well as keeping Puth\u2019s fun and lighthearted style.
At its core, Voicenotes is an acoustic pop album. However, it goes deeper than just putting electric guitars aside; these songs are stripped right down to the bare bones. There\u2019s still plenty of production value\u2014especially on the third track\u2014but it feels like Puth made a conscious decision not to hide behind anything.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: A-Trak's 'in My Feelings' Is a Summer Bop You Need in Your Life
"Boyhood" Is a Coming-Of-Age Story like No Other

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`The coming-of-age trope is one of the most frequently used narrative devices in modern film. From "Stand by Me" to "Superbad," there are countless stories about adolescents transitioning from innocent children into independent adults. However, it is almost unheard of for a film to capture the nuances and absurdities of growing up as effectively as Richard Linklater\u2019s \u201CBoyhood.\u201D The movie documents 12 years in the life of Mason (played by Ellar Coltrane) and his family through a series of carefully crafted vignettes that document the everyday minutiae of life without being clich\xE9 or cloying.
Like so many movies about kids growing up, "Boyhood" begins with young Mason being uprooted from his home in Texas and forced to migrate to new cities as he grows older. What makes this movie unique, however, is that all these major events occur over an 11-year period while Linklater was filming with the same actors at different points in their lives. The result is something like a documentary on human development \u2014 funny, sad, awkward, and everything in between \u2014 presented through the lens of an intimate cinematic experience.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
